title: 113_hr5485
content: The Act may be cited as the "Ravi Thackurdeen Safe Students Study Abroad Act" and applies the Clery Act to programs of study abroad. The Ravi Thackurdeen Safe Students Study Abroad Act amends the reporting of crime statistics for programs of study abroad approved for credit by institutions of higher education. It distinguishes the location of criminal offenses without regard to institutional ownership. The Ravi Thackurdeen Safe Students Study Abroad Act requires institutions of higher education to develop and distribute a statement to protect students in study abroad programs from crime and harm. The Ravi Thackurdeen Safe Students Study Abroad Act mandates biennial reviews of approved study abroad programs to assess their effectiveness in protecting students from harm and crime. The Ravi Thackurdeen Safe Students Study Abroad Act requires biennial reviews of study abroad programs to report on deaths, accidents, illnesses, hospitalizations, sexual assaults, and incidents involving program participants. The Ravi Thackurdeen Safe Students Study Abroad Act mandates biennial reviews of study abroad programs to report on incidents involving program participants resulting in police involvement or a police report, specifying the location of the incidents. The Ravi Thackurdeen Safe Students Study Abroad Act requires biennial reviews of study abroad programs to report incidents involving participants and crime statistics, regardless of location. Institutions must provide interested students with this information. The Ravi Thackurdeen Safe Students Study Abroad Act mandates pre-trip orientation and advising for students participating in approved study abroad programs, including a list of countries, travel warnings, and specific information for each program. The Ravi Thackurdeen Safe Students Study Abroad Act requires institutions to provide pre-trip orientation and post-trip sessions for students participating in approved study abroad programs. The Act also prohibits the disaggregation of information if it could reveal personally identifiable information or if the number of students in a category is too small for reliable data. The Secretary will review study abroad programs at institutions of higher education to protect students from crime and harm while abroad.
